head.title: MAY 17-23: The Vatican; Opus Dei's Founder Steps Closer to Sainthood

hedline.hl1: MAY 17-23: The Vatican; Opus Dei's Founder Steps Closer to Sainthood

block.p: Pope John Paul II gave new stature last week to Opus Dei, a movement that unites 75,000 Roman Catholics in a highly disciplined spiritual life and strict loyalty to papal policy.
At an outdoor Mass in St. Peter's Square, the Pope beatified Msgr. Jose Maria Esciva de Balaguer, the Spaniard who founded the secretive movement in 1928.
Pope John Paul II gave new stature last week to Opus Dei, a movement that unites 75,000 Roman Catholics in a highly disciplined spiritual life and strict loyalty to papal policy.
At an outdoor Mass in St. Peter's Square, the Pope beatified Msgr. Jose Maria Esciva de Balaguer, the Spaniard who founded the secretive movement in 1928.

Granting beatification -- the step before sainthood -- only 17 years after the priest's death provoked a bitter debate. Some liberals argued that Opus Dei had short-circuited the investigation of Monsignor Escriva's holiness and suppressed testimony that he was irascible and vain, made pro-Hitler remarks and even contemplated leaving the church out of disgust at Vatican II reforms.

Opus Dei said the accusations were groundless, and some went further. Paul Johnson, an English left wing intellectual turned conservative, dismissed the complaints as a plot by jealous Jesuits with "more than a whiff of sulphur about it."
